Really good monster management sim with a super fun gameplay loop, charming visuals and a good story. 

I'd say the one issue I had with the game is that its tutorials could be improved slightly, as right now they dump a massive amount of information on the player all at once, though in my opinion this is only a minor issue and once you get past the first hour the game does a very good job of explaining new systems as they are introduced.

That stupid magical girl can eat shit.

When Project Moon decided to make such a story, they made great decision, which for some reason is almost always ignored by other devs and companies, to make a refined world that is not just completely optional part of a game / series, but an essential place for story to unfold, that lives by its rules and is basically one of the forces which makes the story progress. On top of that, world is expanded way more by LobCorp's successors and actually is one of the biggest reasons it got me invested in series in the first place.
Gameplay wise however, LobCorp is absolute torture(but the one you absolutely need to experience yourself). You get a hang of it pretty fast, and 80% of the game can go completely smoothly, but some challenges the game throws at you are absolutely unbearable and make you question your life decisions(yes Hokma, im talking about you). And while it technically makes sense to have a hard time because of story reasons, it still sometimes gets really annoying to replay the same day over and over again just because you didnt get lucky enough.
On top of that, getting 100% abnormality dissolution for epilogue is another questionable decision(the amount of times i had to restart same one week for that is diabolical). Actually made me use speedhacks because i was not willing to replay the game from day 1 for better chances of getting lower level abnormalities. Made me respect Ayin really much though, dude got way more dedication than i had.
Overall, the game is best experienced when you have a ton of free time, but make sure to rest from time to time as it gets kinda frustrating or repetitive sometimes. If you're peak story enjoyer, then Project Moon's world is definitely for you

This game is not for everyone.
You will not be spoon-fed information. You will have to drag it out of the gameplay loop with blood, sweat, and tears.
This game should be treated as a rogue-like, with an expectation of successes being along the lines of "if at first you don't succeed," try and try and try again.
Do not be afraid of starting over: knowledge begets progress.

That being said, the story and the world this game builds defies expectation. The lore is deep and rich and I am still being drawn in again and again after 100 hours of game time. Do *I* recommend this game? Yes. Do I think everyone will enjoy it? Certainly not. But if the idea of an SCP base-management game intrigues you, give it a shot. Just don't lose your head over it.

Game is cool, here's a few things to make your playthrough 100x better than mine:

I highly recommend downloading a couple of mods even for your first playthrough.

I used Optimization and DetailedInfo from Nexus (along with BaseMod). Neither of these really impact your gameplay but Optimization can save you from a potentially disastrous game crash caused by a memory leak (that a certain big, scary monster from the dark, dusky forest inflicted on me upon dying) and DetailedInfo just grants a tad more awareness on the happenings behind the 'Common,' 'Very High,' etc. work results.

The game is fun and people call it hell because of the endgame and boss fights but they're, like Ruina, good tests of your multitasking and planning skills which naturally punish you for any minute error. Yeah it's annoying, but the game gives you some really nice tools such as memory repository to hone your skills.

If you're gonna play and see this review, here's a great piece of info that isn't super well explained in-game:

Returning to the Memory Repository (most recent day ending in 1 or 6) retains ALL of your EGO and Unique PE boxes as well as observation level--however it resets your nuggets (agents) back to the state they were in on that day (EGO gift-wise and back to life if they died). But crucially, mission progress is KEPT. If you finish a boss fight, complete a bunch of missions for multiple departments (including ones you unlock and then revert to a point where you don't have them unlocked anymore), you will keep the mission progress AND respective department research. Resetting to Day 1 has a similar effect of keeping your EGO and mission progress, but it will remove all of your employees. A certain Training Team 'upgrade' will help out a lot if you plan on doing this.

True ending requires 100% main-game abnormality dissolution (observation lv. 4) and completing all Sephirah missions. If you reach Day 45 and haven't done all of these, you WILL have to go back to Day 1.

I personally enjoyed this game, so I've labeled this as a positive review, but truthfully I have no idea who this game should be recommended for.
Bear in mind that this review is coming from someone who has not played the other Project Moon games and does not play video games frequently. I purchased this game and Library of Ruina while they were on sale, and installed Limbus Company because I figured it made sense to do so.

When I first started playing the game, by far the most fun I had was learning about the Abnormalities and how to work with them. I found both the lore and the designs to be quite interesting. I didn't mind restarting a few times to learn how they worked.
At a certain point though, it became too difficult to discover how to manage the Abnormalities on my own. I had to look up how to deal with them, and some of their mechanics were incredibly stressful, even if they weren't difficult to manage. I stopped playing for a while because the amount of different mechanics I had to mentally juggle became too much for me.

Eventually, I returned to the game because I was in the mood to pick up a video game. The biggest reason I chose to return to this game is because of the story, which is quite good. I looked up a guide, and I learned about quite a few unintuitive or poorly explained system mechanics, mostly Day 1 restarts and the Memory Repository. I was able to create a more manageable facility and keep playing, but the joy of discovery had been somewhat lost. Rewinding or resetting my facility was rather tedious as well, and I mostly did so while I was on call with my friends.

I did begin to enjoy the challenge the game posed, and it certainly did feel rewarding when I was able to clear a difficult event. I finished the game with a pretty positive impression of it.
The issue is that this game does require you to enjoy discovery of interesting Abnormalities and characters, and tedious, stressful, and challenging gameplay, which aren't meshed together very well. Quite honestly, I'm not exactly sure whether the time I spent playing this game was worth it or not.

I hope this isn't too negative of a positive review. I think this is a genuinely good game, but I just can't confidently say exactly which types of players would like it. Just be aware that it is quite demanding, and that there will probably be at least a couple parts of the game that you have to force yourself through.

Love the game so far. It definitely took me 8 hours to really get the hang of managing where I need employees to be and not overcommitting with points and equipment. 

Generally this game has quite a few dumb or just slightly annoying quirks with it that I wouldn't blame someone for not having a good time with the game. And I do think it can end up feeling like there's a lot of artificial difficulty due to lack of QOL features it really just should have and unavoidable deaths. (Like it is a bit annoying to have to squint and figure out what gifts each employee has and which slots)

I personally enjoy these games where "the world is hard as balls" and you gotta do the best with what you have. Slowly learning more about it and slowly becoming better at overcoming, but still having to deal with the unfair reality. And I feel the brutality of the game honestly makes the setting a lot more believable. You don't magically control these dangerous anomalies or know how to do it. Even if you learn all you can or such. Like in a world with dangerous scp-like creatures. There's obviously gonna be a lot of outbreaks and death even if you make the perfect facility. It makes the characters a lot more believable and the story more immersive. 

In order to learn, you will lose brutally over and over. Most times it feels unfair (cause it often is) and a lot of the management "hints" are basically useless. Reason being they just tell you information you can figure out with common sense. Like "oh the result has an average chance of lowering if the result was normal/average. Or "bad outcome = high chance of lowering count". uh... like no shit sherlock.

Sometimes it'll give just general info about the anomaly which I honestly am fine with cause you get to learn more about them even if it's not directly helpful. Or details into the lore which I also think is cool. But I do generally think "management tips" should give actual valuable information about managing it. That stuff can just be in the description and unlocked over time maybe?


Some other minor gripes I had with the game...

Why is there a "roguelite" aspect to the game. It gatekeeps QOL features behind a linear progression of quests. Which is just obnoxious and pointless. Also, it literally goes over these features (you won't even have access to) in the tutorial. So it's not even for the sake of not overwhelming the player. 

Additionally, I also feel like there's just not enough information displayed in general. And even when it comes to the controls, for how much micromanagement you can do. I don't understand why you can't choose exactly where an npc will stand. And also sometimes it can be really funky trying to get your employees to stop doing a task like suppressing. I started realizing the "suppression task" usually causes more issues and its easier to just select groups and move them.
True pain and suffering can only come when one walks the path of no turning back. After all keeping your facility alive is harder then it looks.

negative.review:
Art is subjective. I can tell everyone around here enjoys the way difficulty works in this game but I personally did not. So not as to bash the game but to ensure anyone who might share my feelings ignores this game and doesn't lose a precious afternoon, let me tell you why I hate this very good game.

I am the kind of guy who likes to have the ability to think things through and get out of tough spots. I like to work with what I have and make it work. I like saving people like a hero. I like the fantasy of having to power to do that. This game took every character I controlled. Spat in my face. Changed the way the game works, and then proceeded to kill all of them in an instant repeatedly.

The way the game works is that you have several entities in containment that can break out and hurt people. You have the job of testing them to get energy from them with the risk that they can kill the employees under you if they do. Testing them reveals information about them that is useful to help you keep them contained. This information is constantly contradictory. "do a test on an entity with a high rating of (insert skill) and you will test more effectively." then entity two says: "Nah actually I'm going to kill you for doing that. See you next run!" and proceeds to kill 3 of the 7 characters I have at random, with no way to know how to stop it. Instant death to all of them. Doesn't matter if they were your best ones.

Several game mechanics in this are completely random. I maxed out all stats on a character, knew all the info on an entity and then did a test on it. I knew it would have a bad effect if I failed but I knew everything about how to do the test correctly and did that. The entity still broke through containment. Then it literally forced me to roll on a roulette wheel and then killed a character it rolled at random.

Brutal. Now what about that was strategy? Was it the part where I repeated a day over and over to get enough information I needed to figure out what the entity even did? Was it me spending hours to learn without actually getting to proceed with the game? Did I do something wrong? No. I got unlucky. And if I did proceed as normal, I never would have even gotten info on that entity because any info I recieved was erased because I failed the run. I learned nothing. Gained nothing. Have nothing. Start over.

I've spent 33 hours on this trying to figure out the strategy on this game. Do you know what I learned? There isn't any strategy for entities you don't already know. That means your run ends on every new entity and then you start over. Hours of play lost at a time, no power over what to do.

This isn't difficulty. It's memorization. I started making progress when I knew what entities did and started over. It wasn't even hard it was just long and senseless. Characters are meant to be toys that die. Their stories and feelings don't matter. Everyone dies. Your actions don't matter until you've died enough it's extended game play with no actual sauce to it. I'm doing the same thing on repeat every time. I COULD just go to the wiki and follow instructions step by step but then what was the point in me specifically picking up this game? What was the point in me playing it? What did I actually do or add to this?

I feel miserable. I was promised a strategy game and everyone here seems to claim they are having fun. I didn't see the strategy. I can't find the fun. I can't find what I'm even supposed to do. There was no point in me playing this game. To anyone who enjoyed this, can you please tell me where my own decisions mattered? What was I supposed to do? Lose time? Is that why it's hard? You just have to sink time into it? That is hard but it's not challenging. It's not testing my wit. It didn't make me think. It didn't make me fight. I just had to spend time. That's no different than grinding away at monsters in an RPG. I may as well have played Genshin and called it hard because it made me spend time on it. What a waste on this game.

So I'd really like to recommend this game, but I cannot in good faith doing so without the use of mods. The game can be unfun and straight up torturous to play. If I never got mods I'd never even beat this game. You can have hours and hours wasted all because you didn't understand a gimmick or didn't have enough information on an abnormality, where you're fucked. I'd love to say the difficulty is what makes the experience, but that's simply untrue, it feels horrible being screwed to abnormality rng, having to reset the past 4-5 days (which could be from 1-2 hours to nearly 6-8 hours depending on how far you are into the game) which feels horrible to do, over and over again. 

But the story is great, the writing feels cohesive, even though there's an illusion of choice with the dialogue options that i don't really connect with. The rewards when completing missions feel fantastic and always worth doing, there was never an upgrade I felt was bad for my Facility. The characters are all pretty memorable, (besides maybe 1 or 2), and getting to know all of the abnormalities and learning the muscle memory behind the gameplay is addicting.

The bugs can fuck right off, kinda make the game nearly unplayable.

Firstly, The game doesn't hold any punches, at first few management days you're getting fine selection of abnormalties but later you get ones that just there to force you to give up on playing. Secondly, and that's main reason I don't recommend is that it doesn't respect your time at all, one single mistake and half hour worth of progression gone in a blink. The game just consumes your time like plague and you don't get anything in return.

There's also few parts of the game where you got no choice but to just cheese the game, Backward Clock for example is most essential abnormal tool needed to beat most challenges and final days.

The Story is amazing and this is what makes me keep going with gameplay otherwise I would've gave up way early since its not worth hurting my sanity.

TL;DR Just watch on YT if you're here for story. Otherwise you're welcome to try hurting your mentality by playing this game.

Art is subjective. I can tell everyone around here enjoys the way difficulty works in this game but I personally did not. So not as to bash the game but to ensure anyone who might share my feelings ignores this game and doesn't lose a precious afternoon, let me tell you why I hate this very good game.

I am the kind of guy who likes to have the ability to think things through and get out of tough spots. I like to work with what I have and make it work. I like saving people like a hero. I like the fantasy of having to power to do that. This game took every character I controlled. Spat in my face. Changed the way the game works, and then proceeded to kill all of them in an instant repeatedly.

The way the game works is that you have several entities in containment that can break out and hurt people. You have the job of testing them to get energy from them with the risk that they can kill the employees under you if they do. Testing them reveals information about them that is useful to help you keep them contained. This information is constantly contradictory. "do a test on an entity with a high rating of (insert skill) and you will test more effectively." then entity two says: "Nah actually I'm going to kill you for doing that. See you next run!" and proceeds to kill 3 of the 7 characters I have at random, with no way to know how to stop it. Instant death to all of them. Doesn't matter if they were your best ones.

Several game mechanics in this are completely random. I maxed out all stats on a character, knew all the info on an entity and then did a test on it. I knew it would have a bad effect if I failed but I knew everything about how to do the test correctly and did that. The entity still broke through containment. Then it literally forced me to roll on a roulette wheel and then killed a character it rolled at random.

Brutal. Now what about that was strategy? Was it the part where I repeated a day over and over to get enough information I needed to figure out what the entity even did? Was it me spending hours to learn without actually getting to proceed with the game? Did I do something wrong? No. I got unlucky. And if I did proceed as normal, I never would have even gotten info on that entity because any info I recieved was erased because I failed the run. I learned nothing. Gained nothing. Have nothing. Start over.

I've spent 33 hours on this trying to figure out the strategy on this game. Do you know what I learned? There isn't any strategy for entities you don't already know. That means your run ends on every new entity and then you start over. Hours of play lost at a time, no power over what to do.

This isn't difficulty. It's memorization. I started making progress when I knew what entities did and started over. It wasn't even hard it was just long and senseless. Characters are meant to be toys that die. Their stories and feelings don't matter. Everyone dies. Your actions don't matter until you've died enough it's extended game play with no actual sauce to it. I'm doing the same thing on repeat every time. I COULD just go to the wiki and follow instructions step by step but then what was the point in me specifically picking up this game? What was the point in me playing it? What did I actually do or add to this?

I feel miserable. I was promised a strategy game and everyone here seems to claim they are having fun. I didn't see the strategy. I can't find the fun. I can't find what I'm even supposed to do. There was no point in me playing this game. To anyone who enjoyed this, can you please tell me where my own decisions mattered? What was I supposed to do? Lose time? Is that why it's hard? You just have to sink time into it? That is hard but it's not challenging. It's not testing my wit. It didn't make me think. It didn't make me fight. I just had to spend time. That's no different than grinding away at monsters in an RPG. I may as well have played Genshin and called it hard because it made me spend time on it. What a waste on this game.

So I'd really like to recommend this game, but I cannot in good faith doing so without the use of mods. The game can be unfun and straight up torturous to play. If I never got mods I'd never even beat this game. You can have hours and hours wasted all because you didn't understand a gimmick or didn't have enough information on an abnormality, where you're fucked. I'd love to say the difficulty is what makes the experience, but that's simply untrue, it feels horrible being screwed to abnormality rng, having to reset the past 4-5 days (which could be from 1-2 hours to nearly 6-8 hours depending on how far you are into the game) which feels horrible to do, over and over again. 

But the story is great, the writing feels cohesive, even though there's an illusion of choice with the dialogue options that i don't really connect with. The rewards when completing missions feel fantastic and always worth doing, there was never an upgrade I felt was bad for my Facility. The characters are all pretty memorable, (besides maybe 1 or 2), and getting to know all of the abnormalities and learning the muscle memory behind the gameplay is addicting.

The bugs can fuck right off, kinda make the game nearly unplayable.

I came from someone who beated Library of Ruina and Limbus Company (Canto 8 at the time I'm writing this review), I decided to play Lobotomy Corporation, I usually try to endure difficulty spikes gameplay but my God, this game actually ruined me. 

For starters, the game is management sim, I wasn't expert in this kind of game but once you start getting hang of its core gameplay, you can handle gameplay just fine, however there's few points where I don't really recommend playing it unless you're maschoist and desire for one of the most painful experience in videogames.

Firstly, The game doesn't hold any punches, at first few management days you're getting fine selection of abnormalties but later you get ones that just there to force you to give up on playing. I won't spoil much details but one of them you get punished for performing good work. And it gets worse down the road.

Secondly, and that's main reason I don't recommend is that it doesn't respect your time at all, one single mistake and half hour worth of progression gone in a blink. The game just consumes your time like plague and you don't get anything in return.

There's also few parts of the game where you got no choice but to just cheese the game, Backward Clock for example is most essential abnormal tool needed to beat most challenges and final days.

The Story is amazing and this is what makes me keep going with gameplay otherwise I would've gave up way early since its not worth hurting my sanity.
